description:
Notamacropus eugenii, commonly known as the Tammar wallaby, is a small macropod species native to Australia. This marsupial belongs to the family Macropodidae, which includes kangaroos, wallabies, and other similar species.

The Tammar wallaby is characterized by its small to medium size, with an average head-body length of around 45-60 cm and a weight of 4-8 kg. They have a slender build, with a long, narrow head and large, rounded ears. Their fur is typically grey-brown in color, with a paler underside.

These wallabies are found in a variety of habitats, including coastal scrublands, heathlands, and open woodlands. They are primarily herbivorous, feeding on a range of grasses, shrubs, and other vegetation.

Notamacropus eugenii is known for its unique reproductive strategies, including a short gestation period of only 26-28 days and the ability to delay the development of the embryo (embryonic diapause) in response to environmental conditions. This adaptation allows the Tammar wallaby to time the birth of its young to coincide with optimal resource availability.

The Tammar wallaby is considered a species of Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, but some populations have experienced declines due to habitat loss, predation, and competition from introduced species.
